questions.text: A 57-year-old woman comes to the emergency department 1 hour after experiencing a distressing 10-minute episode of stuttering during a business meeting. She has hypertension. She has smoked two packs of cigarettes daily for 30 years. Current medications include fosinopril and hydrochlorothiazide. Her temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 90/min, respirations are 16/min, and blood pressure is 134/88 mm Hg. She is oriented to person, place, and time. Her speech is clear. When she is asked to hold both arms fully extended at shoulder level with palms upwards and eyes closed, her right palm turns inwards and downwards. Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient's physical findings?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Cerebellar lesions typically manifest with ataxia, which can be elicited in the upper extremities by tests such as the finger-to-nose test and the rapid alternating movements test. Furthermore, in patients with a cerebellar lesion, the pronator test typically reveals an upward drift of the hand rather than the downward drift seen here.

B) INCORRECT:

Posterior column lesions usually manifest with fine-touch and proprioception deficits; a positive Romberg test can indicate a lesion to this region. There is no evidence of sensory deficits based on this patient's neurologic examination. The presence of aphasia localizes the lesion to the cortex, and not the spinal cord.

C) INCORRECT:

Lesions to the inferior frontal gyrus of the dominant hemisphere, i.e., Broca area, can result in Broca aphasia with deficits in language production. Although this patient's transitory stuttering could indicate involvement of the Broca area, her speech is clear now. Furthermore, a lesion of the Broca area would not result in a positive pronator drift test.

D) INCORRECT:

Lesions to the superior temporal gyrus of the dominant hemisphere, i.e., Wernicke area, can result in Wernicke aphasia with deficits in language comprehension. However, this patient's transient stuttering suggests a problem with language production rather than language comprehension. Furthermore, a lesion of Wernicke area would not result in a positive pronator drift test.

E) CORRECT:

This patient has several risk factors for stroke (hypertension, smoking history) and, given her acute onset of motor aphasia and the physical exam findings, has likely suffered brain ischemia. Pronator drift is a sensitive test for deficits resulting from lesions of the upper motor neuron (UMN) and can reveal subtle weakness that may be undetectable on traditional confrontation strength testing. UMN lesions manifest with a pattern of weakness that affects the upper extremities supinator muscles more than the pronator muscles. Therefore, when the patient holds her arm outward with palms facing up, the affected arm will drift downward and the palm will turn towards the floor. Based on this patient's transient motor aphasia (cortical sign), the middle cerebral artery territory is most likely affected.

This patient should undergo prompt diagnostic workup for stroke including emergency non-contrast CT scan to rule out hemorrhage.

F) INCORRECT:

This patient's right arm is exhibiting greater supinator than pronator muscle weakness, which could not be explained by a lesion of the thalamus, as this does not contain descending motor fibers. Instead, thalamus lesions typically manifest with pronounced sensory deficits (e.g., contralateral numbness and paresthesias), which are not seen here. Also, this patient presents with transient motor aphasia, which suggests impairment in the middle cerebral artery territory rather than the posterior cerebral artery, which predominantly supplies the thalamus.
Image Description:

A posterior cerebral artery infarct (left-sided here) typically leads to the following:
– Contralateral sensory loss (due to lateral thalamic involvement)
– Contralateral homonymous hemianopsia with macular sparing (because the macula receives collateral vascular supply from the middle cerebral artery)
questions.hint: This woman has a unilaterally positive pronator drift test, which is both sensitive and specific for a lesion of a certain part of the CNS. Further examination may show mild facial droop.

questions.text: A 6-year-old boy is brought to the physician because of a 3-week history of limping. He was born at term and has been healthy since. His immunizations are up-to-date; he received his 5th DTaP vaccine one month ago. He is at the 50th percentile for height and weight. His temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 80/min, and respirations are 28/min. When asked to stand only on his right leg, the left pelvis sags. The remainder of the examination shows no abnormalities. Which of the following is the most likely cause of these findings?

choices.text: Damage to the left inferior gluteal nerve
Damage to the left superior gluteal nerve
Damage to the left common peroneal nerve
Damage to the right common peroneal nerve
Damage to the right superior gluteal nerve
Damage to the right inferior gluteal nerve

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

L5 radiculopathy usually occurs due to herniation of the L4–L5 disc and is seen most often in patients 30–50 years of age. Patients present with severe stabbing, shock-like back pain that radiates to a unilateral leg, weakness of the extensor hallucis longus muscle (which causes foot drop), impaired posterior tibial reflex, and paresthesia of the lateral leg and dorsal foot. This patient has none of these symptoms.
Image Description:

Dorsal view of the lumbosacral spine, spinal cord (at level of conus medullaris/cauda equina transition), and nerve roots

(A) Posterolateral disk herniation (90% of cases): most commonly affects the nerve root below the level of the herniation (L3/L4 disk herniation causes L4 nerve root impingement)

(B,C) Central (posterior) disk herniation: depending on location and extent of herniation, may affect both lumbar and sacral nerve roots (B) or only the sacral nerve roots (C)

(D,E) Far lateral disk herniation: usually affects the nerve root above the level of the herniation (D: L2/L3 disk herniation causes L2 nerve root impingement), and may affect two adjacent nerve roots (E: above and below the level of herniation)

B) INCORRECT:

The left inferior gluteal nerve innervates the left gluteus maximus muscle. This muscle is the primary left thigh extensor; inferior gluteal nerve damage leads to impairment of this function. This nerve is rarely injured, but possible etiologies include misdirected intramuscular injections and procedures (e.g., posterior approach to hip arthroplasty).

C) INCORRECT:

The left superior gluteal nerve innervates the left gluteus medius and minimus, which are responsible for abducting the left hip. Weakness of these muscles would lead to a positive Trendelenburg sign (downward tilting of the pelvis toward the right side) when the patient stands on the left leg.

D) INCORRECT:

Patients with a spinal epidural abscess can present with localized back pain, neurologic deficits, and systemic signs of infection (e.g., fever, malaise). This patient has isolated motor weakness without pain or infectious symptoms, making this diagnosis unlikely. In addition, spinal abscesses typically occur following invasive spinal procedures (e.g. epidural catheter, spinal surgery), in patients with substance use disorders (e.g., due to intravenous drug use), or in patients who are immunocompromised, none of which apply to this patient.

E) INCORRECT:

Injury to the superficial branch of the common peroneal nerve impairs pronation of the foot and sensation of the dorsal lateral leg, foot, and toes. Injury to the deep branch of this nerve on the left side impairs sensation between the first and second toes and dorsiflexion of the foot and toe (leading to left foot drop and a high-stepping gait). This nerve is frequently injured as a result of fibular head fracture or compression to the upper lateral leg (e.g. from wearing a cast, obstetric stirrups, sitting cross-legged). None of these features are seen in this patient.

F) INCORRECT:

Injury to the superficial branch of the common peroneal nerve impairs pronation of the foot and sensation of the dorsal lateral leg, foot, and toes. Injury to the deep branch of this nerve impairs sensation between the first and second toes and dorsiflexion of the foot and toe (leading to right foot drop and a high-stepping gait). This nerve is frequently injured as a result of fibular head fracture or compression to the upper lateral leg (e.g. from wearing a cast, obstetric stirrups, sitting cross-legged). None of these features are seen in this patient, and this patient's muscle weakness is present on the left side.

G) CORRECT:

When a healthy patient stands on the right leg, the pelvis remains horizontal rather than sagging down to the left because the right gluteus medius and minimus muscles engage to abduct the right hip, which tilts the pelvis back to a horizontal level. This patient, however, has a positive Trendelenburg sign, which indicates neurologic insufficiency of the right gluteus medius and minimus muscles. These muscles are innervated by the right superior gluteal nerve. A misdirected intramuscular injection into the gluteal region can cause superior gluteal nerve injury, which is likely what occurred following this patient's DTaP vaccination.
Image Description:

The Trendelenburg sign indicates insufficiency of the gluteus medius and gluteus minimus muscles. It is tested for as follows:
(1) The pelvic level is assessed by comparing the height of both iliac crests.
(2) The patient is asked to stand on one leg, with the examiner continuously observing the level of the pelvis and the patient's posture. Normally, the pelvis is stabilized by the gluteus medius and gluteus minimus muscles, which prevent a pelvic drop to the opposite side.
(3) In the case of muscle insufficiency, the pelvis drops towards the unimpaired, unsupported side (free leg), which is known as the Trendelenburg sign.
(4) Tilting of the torso toward the contralateral side compensates for the pelvic drop on the unimpaired side, which is known as Duchenne sign. Because the Duchenne sign may mask the Trendelenburg sign, it is important to always inspect the patient's overall posture.

H) INCORRECT:

The right inferior gluteal nerve innervates the right gluteus maximus muscle. This muscle is the primary right thigh extensor; inferior gluteal nerve damage impairs this function. This nerve is rarely injured, but possible etiologies include misdirected intramuscular injections and procedures (e.g., posterior approach to hip arthroplasty).
questions.hint: Sagging of the contralateral pelvis when standing on one foot indicates weakness of the gluteus medius and gluteus minimus muscles.

questions.text: A 47-year-old woman comes to the physician because of a 3-month history of recurrent episodes of nausea and feeling like the room is spinning. Each episode lasts less than a minute and usually occurs when she gets out of bed in the morning or suddenly turns her head. She has not vomited and does not have headaches. She is asymptomatic between episodes. Which of the following findings most closely correlates with this patient's symptoms?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Intention tremor is a sign of cerebellar dysfunction that can result from a variety of neurological conditions. While some patients with intention tremor experience dizziness, this is due to disequilibrium secondary to cerebellar dysfunction rather than vestibular dysfunction. Dizziness due to a balance disorder is triggered by walking instead of head rotation, as seen in this patient.

B) CORRECT:

Vertigo and nausea are common symptoms of dysfunctions of the vestibular system, which often also present with pronounced nystagmus. This patient's episodic vertigo triggered by specific types of head movement suggests benign paroxysmal positional vertigo (BPPV), which is confirmed by observing nystagmus during a provoked maneuver such as the Dix Hallpike test.

Patients with a positive Dix Hallpike test for right-sided BPPV (with the head rotated to the right) will have rotational nystagmus with a counterclockwise rapid phase. Clockwise rapid phase nystagmus on rotation to the left is positive for left-sided BPPV.

C) INCORRECT:

A positive Romberg test is indicative of dysfunction of the dorsal columns, which can result from conditions such as longstanding uncontrolled diabetes mellitus or syphilis. Dorsal column dysfunction leads to sensory ataxia, which may manifest with vertigo. However, vertigo due to a sensory ataxia is triggered by movement of the extremities instead of head rotation as the symptoms in this patient.

D) INCORRECT:

Binocular diplopia, commonly known as double vision, is a sign of dysfunction of the extraocular muscles. While visual impairment can induce vertigo, it is not triggered by head rotation as in this patient.

E) INCORRECT:

An abnormal Rinne test is a sign of conductive hearing loss, which can be caused by a variety of conditions, including cerumen impaction, otosclerosis, and otitis media. Although these conditions can cause dizziness, this patient's pattern of episodic vertigo triggered by specific types of head movement indicates a different cause for her symptoms.

F) INCORRECT:

Orthostatic hypotension is an episodic phenomenon that causes dizziness or faintness upon standing and may indicate cardiac or neurologic disease if it becomes recurrent. Although orthostatic hypotension is episodic, it does not present with vertigo and nausea as experienced by this patient. Furthermore, while orthostatic hypotension has positional triggers such as standing up, turning of the head does not trigger symptoms.

G) INCORRECT:

Expressive aphasia, also known as Broca aphasia, is a sign of dysfunction of the frontal lobe at the inferior frontal gyrus. Brain lesions can cause central vertigo, but this is usually due to lesions of the brain stem or cerebellum, not the frontal lobe. This patient's vertigo is episodic rather than chronic, as would be expected in a patient with lesions of the CNS.
questions.hint: This patient presents with vertigo and nausea, which are common symptoms of a vestibular disorder.

questions.text: A 28-year-old woman comes to the physician because of a 4-day history of lower extremity numbness, weakness, and urinary incontinence. She has not had any trauma. Neurologic examination shows bilateral lower extremity weakness. Stroking the lateral side of the sole of the foot from the heel to the base of the small toe and medially to the base of the big toe elicits dorsiflexion of the big toe and fanning of the other toes. Further examination of this patient is most likely to show which of the following additional findings?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Muscle spasticity is due to hyperexcitable tonic reflexes and occurs when upper motor neuron (UMN) regulation of alpha motor neurons is lost, which leads to net disinhibition of the spinal reflexes. The Babinski reflex is a primitive reflex mediated by the extrapyramidal tracts. It is lost progressively as the pyramidal tracts gain functionality through increasing myelination. As such, a positive Babinski reflex is normal in children up to 1 year of age, after which time it is usually suppressed by the pyramidal tracts.

In combination with urinary incontinence, signs of upper motor neuron damage in an otherwise healthy young woman raise suspicion of multiple sclerosis.

B) INCORRECT:

The palmar grasp reflex is a primitive reflex elicited in infants that persists until 3–6 months of age. A positive palmar grasp reflex in an adult may be a sign of frontal lobe damage (frontal release sign). It does not indicate upper motor neuron damage.

C) INCORRECT:

A decrease in the activity of a reflex arc points to injuries in the efferent arm of the loop (i.e., lower motor neuron damage). In contrast, the presence of upper motor neuron damage will lead to an increase in reflex strength (i.e., hyperreflexia).

D) INCORRECT:

Isolated fasciculations without further medical signs are benign but indicate lower motor neuron damage if they are accompanied by muscle weakness. Muscle fasciculations would be unlikely in this patient, given that her examination indicates upper motor neuron damage (positive Babinski reflex).

E) INCORRECT:

In combination with muscle weakness, atrophy of muscles isolated to a specific root or peripheral nerve suggests damage to the lower motor neurons. However, a positive Babinski sign points to upper motor neuron damage.
questions.hint: This patient has a positive Babinski sign (extension of the hallux with abduction of all toes), which indicates damage to the corticospinal tract (i.e., upper motor neurons).

questions.text: A 73-year-old man is brought to the emergency department 30 minutes after the sudden onset of right-sided body weakness. His wife reports that he does not seem to understand simple questions. He has type 2 diabetes mellitus and has smoked one pack of cigarettes daily for 45 years. The patient speaks fluently, but he answers questions with nonsensical phrases and cannot repeat single words. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Broca aphasia is caused by lesions in the inferior frontal gyrus of the dominant (usually left) hemisphere (e.g., due to an infarct in the superior division of the middle cerebral artery). In patients with Broca aphasia, language production is greatly affected, resulting in nonfluent, telegraphic, and grammatically incorrect speech, whereas this patient speaks fluently. Patients with Broca aphasia are aware of their impaired speech and can become frustrated during the physical examination, but this patient is unaware of his language deficits. Inability to repeat single words and impaired language comprehension are not typically seen in Broca aphasia.

B) INCORRECT:

Conduction aphasia is usually caused by damage to the arcuate fasciculus. This type of aphasia is characterized by impaired repetition with fluent speech and intact comprehension. This patient has poor repetition with fluent speech but impaired comprehension.

C) INCORRECT:

Transcortical motor aphasia is characterized by nonfluent aphasia with good comprehension and intact repetition. This patient speaks fluently but has impaired comprehension and poor repetition.

D) INCORRECT:

Global aphasia is a neurologic insult that involves nonfluent aphasia and impaired comprehension. Global aphasia is usually caused by a large lesion affecting the Broca area, the Wernicke area, and the arcuate fasciculus. This patient has impaired comprehension and repetition but speaks fluently.

E) CORRECT:

Wernicke aphasia is caused by lesions in the superior temporal gyrus of the dominant (usually left) hemisphere, usually along the left middle cerebral artery (MCA) distribution. Patients with Wernicke aphasia typically present with impaired repetition and language comprehension; although they can speak fluently, they produce nonsensical phrases. Furthermore, these patients lack awareness of their impairment, as is the case here. In addition to Wernicke aphasia, signs of an MCA stroke include gaze deviation towards the side of the infarction and contralateral homonymous hemianopia without macular sparing.

See “Types of aphasia” table.
Image Description:

The different types of aphasia can be divided by the presence of good or poor comprehension (red versus blue), good or poor repetition (top three versus bottom three), as well as nonfluent or fluent (light grey versus dark grey).

F) INCORRECT:

Transcortical sensory aphasia is characterized by impaired comprehension with intact repetition and fluent speech. This patient has fluent speech with impaired comprehension, but his repetition is poor.

G) INCORRECT:

Anomic aphasia is a type of expressive aphasia characterized by word-finding difficulties, particularly in relation to nouns and verbs. Patients with anomic aphasia usually have fluent speech and intact comprehension. This patient speaks fluently but has impaired comprehension and poor repetition.
questions.hint: Sudden onset of right-sided body weakness in conjunction with meaningless speech and impaired comprehension should raise concern for a cerebral lesion located in the posterior part of the left superior temporal gyrus (i.e., occlusion of the left middle cerebral artery).

questions.text: An 81-year-old woman comes to the office for a routine health maintenance examination. She lives in a senior living facility in the Midwestern United States. There have been several cases of heavy metal poisoning through drinking water in her state, and she is concerned about potential exposure to toxic substances. She has a history of hypertension and hyperlipidemia. Her medications include lisinopril and atorvastatin. She does not smoke or drink alcohol. She is 153 cm (5 ft 0 in) tall and weighs 60 kg (132 lb); BMI is 26 kg/m2. Pulse is 76/min and regular, and blood pressure is 136/88 mm Hg. Which of the following neurologic examination findings in this patient would necessitate immediate investigation?

choices.text: Decreased vibration sensation in the great toe

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

High-frequency, progressive, bilateral hearing loss in an older patient suggests presbycusis, which affects more than 50% of individuals at the age of 75 years, with increasing prevalence in older age groups. This condition is caused by age-related damage to hair cells at the base of the cochlea. Although otoscopy and audiometry would eventually be indicated to establish the diagnosis, high-frequency hearing loss is an expected finding in older patients and does not require immediate investigation.

B) CORRECT:

Vertical or rotatory nystagmus on neurologic examination is considered abnormal in all age groups and warrants immediate investigation. Causes for vertical nystagmus include vestibular conditions (e.g., anterior and posterior semicircular canal BPPV), severe alcohol intoxication, drug side effects (e.g., phencyclidine, lithium, carbamazepine, phenytoin), Wernicke encephalopathy, and CNS lesions (e.g., bilateral internuclear ophthalmoplegia in multiple sclerosis, cerebellar lesions). In contrast, although horizontal nystagmus is most frequently pathological, it can occur physiologically (e.g., end-gaze nystagmus) in all age groups. Other neurophthalmological findings considered normal in older patients (especially those aged over 80 years) are sluggish convergence, sluggish pupillary reflex, decreased upward gaze (while lateral and downward movements usually remain intact), and impaired accommodation (presbyopia).
Image Description:

In jerk nystagmus, there is a slow drift phase followed by a fast corrective phase. The name of the nystagmus is determined by the direction of movement in the fast phase (left horizontal, right horizontal, downbeat, upbeat, clockwise, or counterclockwise).

C) INCORRECT:

A decreased sensation of vibration in the distal lower extremities is common in older patients. It can be attributed to the age-related degeneration of distal sensory axons and does not require immediate investigation if it is an isolated finding. Further diagnostic workup is indicated if the decreased sensation of vibration occurs alongside additional signs and symptoms (e.g., signs of ischemia, ulcers, loss of reflexes, concomitant involvement of upper extremities, changes to other types of sensation).

D) INCORRECT:

Decreased sense of smell (hyposmia) is a common finding in older patients, affecting more than 60% of individuals aged ≥ 80 years. This finding can be attributed to the age-related degeneration of olfactory neurons. The isolated finding of hyposmia/anosmia in an older patient does not require immediate investigation. Hyposmia in patients < 60 years of age should raise concern for an underlying disease (e.g., Parkinson disease) and further diagnostic workup might be indicated.

E) INCORRECT:

Diminished or absent ankle jerk reflexes are a common finding in older patients. This finding can be attributed to the age-related degeneration of distal sensory axons, which results in diminished or absent deep tendon reflexes. The isolated finding of absent ankle jerk reflexes in an older patient does not require immediate investigation. Further diagnostic workup is indicated if this finding occurs with additional signs and symptoms, e.g., muscle weakness, sensory changes, constitutional symptoms, asymmetry, back pain.
questions.hint: This finding can be observed on examination of the cranial nerves.

questions.text:
A previously healthy 3-year-old boy is evaluated for abnormal movements. His parents report that for the past 3 days, he has had a random, continuous movement of his right hand, extending to his arm and face, and his speech slurs intermittently during these movements. Every time he extends his arm, the movements seem to worsen.
The parents do not recall any recent infections or upper respiratory symptoms in their son during the past month, although a child at his daycare did have a streptococcal infection last week. The patient’s medical history includes congenital hypothyroidism diagnosed via newborn screen; hypotonia during infancy, which resolved after starting physical therapy; and asthma. His current medications are albuterol and levothyroxine, with no recent changes in dosing, and amoxicillin for an otitis media.
His father has a history of abnormal movements that began at age 5 and resolved by his teen years, and multiple family members on the paternal side have a history of tics diagnosed at an early age. In addition, the patient’s older brother has a history of attention deficit-hyperactivity disorder for which he is taking medication.
On physical examination, the patient is afebrile with normal vital signs for his age. There is no erythema or exudate in his throat. His heart sounds are unremarkable with no audible murmur. No rash is evident on skin evaluation. You witness the movements, which seem random, distinct, flowing, and purposeless — starting at his hand and traveling through the arm, all the way to the face.
An antistreptolysin O titer and thyroid-stimulating hormone level are both in the normal range.
What is the most likely diagnosis in this case?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Drug-induced chorea has been reported with multiple medications, including stimulants used to treat attention deficit-hyperactivity disorder. Accidental ingestion should always be considered in toddlers, and a list of household medications should be obtained. In this case, the clinical picture, including absence of other toxic symptoms, and the strong family history suggest a hereditary cause of chorea. Amoxicillin is not known to cause chorea.

B) INCORRECT:

The majority of childhood-onset disorders characterized by chorea are acquired, with acute or subacute onset. Sydenham chorea is the most commonly acquired chorea in children aged 5 to 15 years. It is a major diagnostic criterion of acute rheumatic fever, a nonsuppurative complication and sequela of group A beta-hemolytic streptococci (GABHS) infection. Elevated measurements of both antistreptolysin O (ASO) and anti-deoxyribonuclease B titers are markers of prior infection with GABHS. In this case, the patient has negative ASO test results despite a possible recent contact at his day care, so this is not the most likely diagnosis.

C) CORRECT:

Chorea refers to a sequence of one or more discrete involuntary movements or movement fragments that appear random given their variable timing, duration, rate, direction, and location; all body parts may be involved. Choreic movements usually worsen during attempted voluntary action and can interfere with purposeful movement, causing functional impairment. Given this patient’s personal history of congenital hypothyroidism, asthma, and infant hypotonia, as well as his family history, the most likely diagnosis is benign hereditary chorea (BHC).

BHC is a rare, autosomal dominant, nonprogressive, hyperkinetic movement disorder characterized by the onset of symptoms before 5 years of age. It is sometimes referred to as brain-thyroid-lung syndrome, because thyroid and lung disease are present in approximately 80% of cases. The neurologic course of BHC involves hypotonia in infancy, followed by the onset of chorea between the ages of 8 months and 5 years, with a fairly stable course in childhood. Chorea may be isolated or accompanied by myoclonus, dystonia, or tics. It may improve after puberty and resolve in some adults.

Key learning point: Benign hereditary chorea is a rare, autosomal dominant, nonprogressive, hyperkinetic movement disorder characterized by the onset of symptoms before 5 years of age.

D) INCORRECT:

Chorea caused by endocrine disorders such as hyperthyroidism, hypoparathyroidism, and hyperglycemia may also be considered in the appropriate clinical setting and ruled out with laboratory testing. Hyperthyroidism can cause chorea, but usually tachycardia, diarrhea, and skin changes are also present. In this case, the patient has no other associated symptoms and has a normal thyroid-stimulating hormone level.

E) INCORRECT:

Huntington disease is a neurodegenerative disorder that produces chorea, cognitive decline, and psychiatric disturbances in adults. Juvenile or childhood-onset disease typically produces parkinsonism and dystonia. Chorea may occur in the context of this condition but is generally not the presenting feature, making it unlikely in this patient.

questions.text: A 47-year-old woman comes to the office because of a 3-month history of recurrent episodes of nausea and feeling like the room is spinning. Each episode lasts less than a minute and usually occurs when she gets out of bed in the morning or suddenly turns her head. She has not vomited and does not have headaches. She is asymptomatic between episodes. Which of the following findings most closely correlates with this patient's symptoms?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Intention tremor is a sign of cerebellar dysfunction that can result from a variety of neurological conditions. While some patients with intention tremor experience dizziness, this is due to disequilibrium secondary to cerebellar dysfunction rather than vestibular dysfunction. Dizziness due to a balance disorder is triggered by walking instead of head rotation, as seen in this patient.

B) CORRECT:

Vertigo and nausea are common symptoms of dysfunctions of the vestibular system, which often also present with pronounced nystagmus. This patient's episodic vertigo triggered by specific types of head movement suggests benign paroxysmal positional vertigo (BPPV), which is confirmed by observing nystagmus during a provoked maneuver such as the Dix Hallpike test.

Patients with a positive Dix Hallpike test for right-sided BPPV (with the head rotated to the right) will have rotational nystagmus with a counterclockwise rapid phase. Clockwise rapid phase nystagmus on rotation to the left is positive for left-sided BPPV.

C) INCORRECT:

An abnormal Rinne test is a sign of conductive hearing loss, which can be caused by a variety of conditions, including cerumen impaction, otosclerosis, and otitis media. Although these conditions can cause dizziness, this patient's pattern of episodic vertigo triggered by specific types of head movement indicates a different cause for her symptoms.

D) INCORRECT:

Orthostatic hypotension is an episodic phenomenon that causes dizziness or faintness upon standing and may indicate cardiac or neurologic disease if it becomes recurrent. Although orthostatic hypotension is episodic, it does not present with vertigo and nausea as experienced by this patient. Furthermore, while orthostatic hypotension has positional triggers such as standing up, turning of the head does not trigger symptoms.

E) INCORRECT:

Expressive aphasia, also known as Broca aphasia, is a sign of dysfunction of the frontal lobe at the inferior frontal gyrus. Brain lesions can cause central vertigo, but this is usually due to lesions of the brain stem or cerebellum, not the frontal lobe. This patient's vertigo is episodic rather than chronic, as would be expected in a patient with lesions of the CNS.
questions.hint: This patient presents with vertigo and nausea, which are common symptoms of a vestibular disorder.

questions.text: A 60-year-old man with sudden speech changes speaks fluently but makes little sense. He struggles to follow verbal instructions. Which lesion is most likely responsible for these findings?

choices.text: Posterior superior temporal gyrus dominant hemisphere

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

The dominant arcuate fasciculus connects language production and comprehension areas. Its disruption causes conduction aphasia, marked by fluent speech, preserved comprehension, and impaired repetition. The patient's comprehension deficits and nonsensical speech suggest a lesion in language comprehension areas, not the arcuate fasciculus.

B) INCORRECT:

The inferior frontal gyrus, corresponding to Broca area, is involved in motor aspects of language production. Lesions here cause Broca aphasia, characterized by nonfluent, effortful speech with intact comprehension. The patient's fluent, nonsensical speech and impaired comprehension align with Wernicke aphasia, not a lesion in the inferior frontal gyrus.

C) INCORRECT:

The dominant angular gyrus is involved in high-level language functions like reading and writing. Lesions here cause alexia, agraphia, and Gerstmann syndrome features, not fluent aphasia with poor comprehension. The patient's symptoms suggest impairment in primary auditory language comprehension, not the angular gyrus.

D) CORRECT:

Wernicke aphasia manifests with fluent but nonsensical speech and impaired language comprehension. This condition is associated with lesions in the posterior superior temporal gyrus of the dominant hemisphere, a region crucial for processing auditory language input. Damage here disrupts the integration of phonological and semantic information, leading to speech that is rhythmically normal but lacks coherent content. This area is often affected in vascular events involving the inferior division of the middle cerebral artery, and neuroimaging typically shows lesions in this anatomical distribution.

Key learning point: A lesion in Wernicke area results in Wernicke aphasia, characterized by fluent but nonsensical speech and impaired comprehension of spoken and written language.

questions.text: A 68-year-old man is brought to the emergency department two hours after the sudden onset of speech difficulty. On examination, he is alert and able to follow commands. He understands spoken and written language, but has difficulty forming words. His speech is nonfluent, slow, and effortful. He attempts to speak but produces short phrases with poor grammar. Naming and repetition are impaired. Damage to which of the following structures best explains this patient’s clinical findings?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

The medial longitudinal fasciculus (MLF) is a paired brainstem tract that interconnects the abducens, oculomotor, and trochlear nuclei to coordinate conjugate horizontal eye movements. The MLF does not have a role in speech production. Lesions of the MLF produce internuclear ophthalmoplegia (impaired adduction of the ipsilateral eye and nystagmus of the contralateral abducting eye).

B) CORRECT:

Damage to the posterior part of the inferior frontal gyrus in the dominant hemisphere (Broca area) impairs the brain’s ability to coordinate the complex motor functions required for speech production, resulting in a nonfluent, slow, and effortful speech with short, poorly constructed phrases and impaired repetition. Since this region is not the primary center for language comprehension, patients are typically still able to understand both spoken and written language. These features are characteristic of Broca aphasia, i.e., expressive aphasia (see “Types of aphasia” table).

Key learning point: A lesion in Broca area (inferior frontal gyrus) causes expressive aphasia.
Image Description:

The primary motor cortex, in the frontal lobe, is the origin of the fibers of the pyramidal tract.

The primary and secondary auditory cortices, where auditory input is processed, are located in the temporal lobe. The primary visual cortex is located at the occipital pole and is surrounded by the secondary visual cortex.

Different functions converge at association areas. The most well-known examples are the motor (Broca) and sensory (Wernicke) areas of speech, which are commonly located in the dominant hemisphere.

C) INCORRECT:

Lesions of the superior temporal gyrus in the dominant hemisphere cause Wernicke aphasia (receptive aphasia), resulting in fluent but nonsensical speech with poor comprehension and impaired repetition. This patient has preserved understanding but has slow, effortful speech, making a lesion in the superior temporal gyrus unlikely.

D) INCORRECT:

Lesions in the arcuate fasciculus disrupt the connection between language comprehension and production, typically resulting in conduction aphasia. Although conduction aphasia can manifest with impaired repetition, both comprehension and fluency are mostly intact, making a lesion in the arcuate fasciculus unlikely.

E) INCORRECT:

The angular gyrus, located in the parietal lobe, is involved in processes such as reading and writing. Lesions in this area are associated with agraphia, alexia, and sometimes Gerstmann syndrome. This patient presents with nonfluent speech, making a lesion in a different structure more likely.
questions.hint: Patients with this type of aphasia are typically aware of their language deficits, which often leads to frustration during communication attempts.

questions.text: You are seeing a 6-year-old boy who is brought to your clinic with a 3-week history of limping. He was born at term and has been healthy. His immunizations are up to date; he received his 5th DTaP vaccine one month ago. He is at the 50th percentile for height and weight. His temperature is 37.0°C, pulse is 80/min, and respirations are 28/min. When asked to stand on his right leg, the left side of his pelvis drops. The rest of the examination is normal. Which one of the following is the most likely cause of these findings?

choices.text: Damage to the right inferior gluteal nerve.
Damage to the left common peroneal nerve.
Damage to the left superior gluteal nerve.
Damage to the left inferior gluteal nerve.
Damage to the right superior gluteal nerve.

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

The right inferior gluteal nerve innervates the right gluteus maximus muscle. This muscle is the primary right thigh extensor; inferior gluteal nerve damage impairs this function. This nerve is rarely injured, but possible etiologies include misdirected intramuscular injections and procedures (e.g., posterior approach to hip arthroplasty).

B) INCORRECT:

Injury to the superficial branch of the common peroneal nerve impairs pronation of the foot and sensation of the dorsal lateral leg, foot, and toes. Injury to the deep branch of this nerve on the left side impairs sensation between the first and second toes and dorsiflexion of the foot and toe (leading to left foot drop and a high-stepping gait). This nerve is frequently injured as a result of fibular head fracture or compression to the upper lateral leg (e.g. from wearing a cast, obstetric stirrups, sitting cross-legged). None of these features are seen in this patient.

C) INCORRECT:

The left superior gluteal nerve innervates the left gluteus medius and minimus, which are responsible for abducting the left hip. Weakness of these muscles would lead to a positive Trendelenburg sign (downward tilting of the pelvis toward the right side) when the patient stands on the left leg.

D) INCORRECT:

The left inferior gluteal nerve innervates the left gluteus maximus muscle. This muscle is the primary left thigh extensor; inferior gluteal nerve damage leads to impairment of this function. This nerve is rarely injured, but possible etiologies include misdirected intramuscular injections and procedures (e.g., posterior approach to hip arthroplasty).

E) CORRECT:

When a healthy patient stands on the right leg, the pelvis remains horizontal rather than sagging down to the left because the right gluteus medius and minimus muscles engage to abduct the right hip, which tilts the pelvis back to a horizontal level. This patient, however, has a positive Trendelenburg sign, which indicates neurologic insufficiency of the right gluteus medius and minimus muscles. These muscles are innervated by the right superior gluteal nerve. A misdirected intramuscular injection into the gluteal region can cause superior gluteal nerve injury, which is likely what occurred following this patient's DTaP vaccination.

Key learning point: Injury to the superior gluteal nerve impairs gluteus medius and minimus function, causing a positive Trendelenburg sign with pelvic drop on the contralateral side when standing on the affected leg.
Image Description:

The Trendelenburg sign indicates insufficiency of the gluteus medius and gluteus minimus muscles. It is tested for as follows:
(1) The pelvic level is assessed by comparing the height of both iliac crests.
(2) The patient is asked to stand on one leg, with the examiner continuously observing the level of the pelvis and the patient's posture. Normally, the pelvis is stabilized by the gluteus medius and gluteus minimus muscles, which prevent a pelvic drop to the opposite side.
(3) In the case of muscle insufficiency, the pelvis drops towards the unimpaired, unsupported side (free leg), which is known as the Trendelenburg sign.
(4) Tilting of the torso toward the contralateral side compensates for the pelvic drop on the unimpaired side, which is known as Duchenne sign. Because the Duchenne sign may mask the Trendelenburg sign, it is important to always inspect the patient's overall posture.
questions.hint: Sagging of the contralateral pelvis when standing on one foot indicates weakness of the gluteus medius and gluteus minimus muscles.

questions.text: You are seeing a 73-year-old man who is brought to the emergency department 30 minutes after sudden onset of right-sided weakness. His wife reports that he does not seem to understand simple questions. He has a history of type 2 diabetes mellitus and has smoked one pack of cigarettes daily for 45 years. He speaks fluently, but answers questions with nonsensical phrases and is unable to repeat single words. Which one of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Global aphasia is a neurologic insult that involves nonfluent aphasia and impaired comprehension. Global aphasia is usually caused by a large lesion affecting the Broca area, the Wernicke area, and the arcuate fasciculus. This patient has impaired comprehension and repetition but speaks fluently.

B) INCORRECT:

Conduction aphasia is usually caused by damage to the arcuate fasciculus. This type of aphasia is characterized by impaired repetition with fluent speech and intact comprehension. This patient has poor repetition with fluent speech but impaired comprehension.

C) INCORRECT:

Transcortical sensory aphasia is characterized by impaired comprehension with intact repetition and fluent speech. This patient has fluent speech with impaired comprehension, but his repetition is poor.

D) CORRECT:

Wernicke aphasia is caused by lesions in the superior temporal gyrus of the dominant (usually left) hemisphere, usually along the left middle cerebral artery (MCA) distribution. Patients with Wernicke aphasia typically present with impaired repetition and language comprehension; although they can speak fluently, they produce nonsensical phrases. Furthermore, these patients lack awareness of their impairment, as is the case here. In addition to Wernicke aphasia, signs of an MCA stroke include gaze deviation towards the side of the infarction and contralateral homonymous hemianopia without macular sparing.

See “Types of aphasia” table.

Key learning point: Wernicke aphasia presents with fluent but nonsensical speech, impaired comprehension, poor repetition, and lack of awareness of language deficits due to a lesion in the dominant superior temporal gyrus.
Image Description:

The different types of aphasia can be divided by the presence of good or poor comprehension (red versus blue), good or poor repetition (top three versus bottom three), as well as nonfluent or fluent (light grey versus dark grey).

E) INCORRECT:

Broca aphasia is caused by lesions in the inferior frontal gyrus of the dominant (usually left) hemisphere (e.g., due to an infarct in the superior division of the middle cerebral artery). In patients with Broca aphasia, language production is greatly affected, resulting in nonfluent, telegraphic, and grammatically incorrect speech, whereas this patient speaks fluently. Patients with Broca aphasia are aware of their impaired speech and can become frustrated during the physical examination, but this patient is unaware of his language deficits. Inability to repeat single words and impaired language comprehension are not typically seen in Broca aphasia.
questions.hint: Sudden onset of right-sided body weakness in conjunction with meaningless speech and impaired comprehension should raise concern for a cerebral lesion located in the posterior part of the left superior temporal gyrus (i.e., occlusion of the left middle cerebral artery).

questions.text: An 81-year-old woman comes to your clinic for a routine health maintenance examination. She lives in a senior living facility in Yellowknife, Northwest Territories. She is concerned about possible exposure to toxic substances due to several recent cases of heavy metal poisoning through drinking water in her territory. Her medical history includes hypertension and hyperlipidemia. Her medications are lisinopril and atorvastatin. She does not smoke or drink alcohol. She is 153 cm tall and weighs 60 kg; BMI is 26. Pulse is 76/min and regular, and blood pressure is 136/88 mm Hg. Which one of the following neurologic examination findings in this patient would necessitate immediate investigation?

choices.text: Decreased vibration sensation in the great toe.

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Diminished or absent ankle jerk reflexes are a common finding in older patients. This finding can be attributed to the age-related degeneration of distal sensory axons, which results in diminished or absent deep tendon reflexes. The isolated finding of absent ankle jerk reflexes in an older patient does not require immediate investigation. Further diagnostic workup is indicated if this finding occurs with additional signs and symptoms, e.g., muscle weakness, sensory changes, constitutional symptoms, asymmetry, back pain.

B) INCORRECT:

A decreased sensation of vibration in the distal lower extremities is common in older patients. It can be attributed to the age-related degeneration of distal sensory axons and does not require immediate investigation if it is an isolated finding. Further diagnostic workup is indicated if the decreased sensation of vibration occurs alongside additional signs and symptoms (e.g., signs of ischemia, ulcers, loss of reflexes, concomitant involvement of upper extremities, changes to other types of sensation).

C) INCORRECT:

Decreased sense of smell (hyposmia) is a common finding in older patients, affecting more than 60% of individuals aged ≥ 80 years. This finding can be attributed to the age-related degeneration of olfactory neurons. The isolated finding of hyposmia/anosmia in an older patient does not require immediate investigation. Hyposmia in patients < 60 years of age should raise concern for an underlying disease (e.g., Parkinson disease) and further diagnostic workup might be indicated.

D) INCORRECT:

High-frequency, progressive, bilateral hearing loss in an older patient suggests presbycusis, which affects more than 50% of individuals at the age of 75 years, with increasing prevalence in older age groups. This condition is caused by age-related damage to hair cells at the base of the cochlea. Although otoscopy and audiometry would eventually be indicated to establish the diagnosis, high-frequency hearing loss is an expected finding in older patients and does not require immediate investigation.

E) CORRECT:

Vertical or rotatory nystagmus on neurologic examination is considered abnormal in all age groups and warrants immediate investigation. Causes for vertical nystagmus include vestibular conditions (e.g., anterior and posterior semicircular canal BPPV), severe alcohol intoxication, drug side effects (e.g., phencyclidine, lithium, carbamazepine, phenytoin), Wernicke encephalopathy, and CNS lesions (e.g., bilateral internuclear ophthalmoplegia in multiple sclerosis, cerebellar lesions). In contrast, although horizontal nystagmus is most frequently pathological, it can occur physiologically (e.g., end-gaze nystagmus) in all age groups. Other neurophthalmological findings considered normal in older patients (especially those aged over 80 years) are sluggish convergence, sluggish pupillary reflex, decreased upward gaze (while lateral and downward movements usually remain intact), and impaired accommodation (presbyopia).

Key learning point: Vertical nystagmus is always abnormal and requires immediate investigation, as it may indicate serious central nervous system or vestibular pathology.
Image Description:

In jerk nystagmus, there is a slow drift phase followed by a fast corrective phase. The name of the nystagmus is determined by the direction of movement in the fast phase (left horizontal, right horizontal, downbeat, upbeat, clockwise, or counterclockwise).
questions.hint: This finding can be observed on examination of the cranial nerves.

questions.text: A 47-year-old woman comes to your clinic with a 3-month history of recurrent episodes of nausea and a sensation that the room is spinning. Each episode lasts less than a minute and typically occurs when she gets out of bed in the morning or suddenly turns her head. She has not vomited and does not have headaches. She is asymptomatic between episodes. Which one of the following findings most closely correlates with her symptoms?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Vertigo and nausea are common symptoms of dysfunctions of the vestibular system, which often also present with pronounced nystagmus. This patient's episodic vertigo triggered by specific types of head movement suggests benign paroxysmal positional vertigo (BPPV), which is confirmed by observing nystagmus during a provoked maneuver such as the Dix Hallpike test.

Patients with a positive Dix Hallpike test for right-sided BPPV (with the head rotated to the right) will have rotational nystagmus with a counterclockwise rapid phase. Clockwise rapid phase nystagmus on rotation to the left is positive for left-sided BPPV.

Key learning point: Benign paroxysmal positional vertigo (BPPV) is characterized by brief episodes of vertigo triggered by head movement and is confirmed by positional nystagmus during maneuvers like the Dix-Hallpike test.

B) INCORRECT:

Orthostatic hypotension is an episodic phenomenon that causes dizziness or faintness upon standing and may indicate cardiac or neurologic disease if it becomes recurrent. Although orthostatic hypotension is episodic, it does not present with vertigo and nausea as experienced by this patient. Furthermore, while orthostatic hypotension has positional triggers such as standing up, turning of the head does not trigger symptoms.

C) INCORRECT:

An abnormal Rinne test is a sign of conductive hearing loss, which can be caused by a variety of conditions, including cerumen impaction, otosclerosis, and otitis media. Although these conditions can cause dizziness, this patient's pattern of episodic vertigo triggered by specific types of head movement indicates a different cause for her symptoms.

D) INCORRECT:

Expressive aphasia, also known as Broca aphasia, is a sign of dysfunction of the frontal lobe at the inferior frontal gyrus. Brain lesions can cause central vertigo, but this is usually due to lesions of the brain stem or cerebellum, not the frontal lobe. This patient's vertigo is episodic rather than chronic, as would be expected in a patient with lesions of the CNS.

E) INCORRECT:

Intention tremor is a sign of cerebellar dysfunction that can result from a variety of neurological conditions. While some patients with intention tremor experience dizziness, this is due to disequilibrium secondary to cerebellar dysfunction rather than vestibular dysfunction. Dizziness due to a balance disorder is triggered by walking instead of head rotation, as seen in this patient.
questions.hint: This patient presents with vertigo and nausea, which are common symptoms of a vestibular disorder.

questions.text: A 52-year-old woman with type 2 diabetes presents to the emergency department with a 6-hour history of abnormal sensations in her right foot. She states that earlier in the day she noticed tingling and pins-and-needles sensations that occurred spontaneously without any trigger. However, over the past 2 hours, the sensation has changed and now even light contact from socks causes intense burning and electric shock-like pain. Physical examination shows that light touch with a cotton swab to the affected area reproduces the unpleasant burning sensation. What term best describes this patient's current sensory abnormality?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Hypesthesia is the decreased perception of sensory stimuli, with anesthesia being the most extreme case. This patient is experiencing heightened unpleasant sensations rather than decreased sensation.

B) INCORRECT:

Pallhypesthesia is a diminished or lost sense of vibration, typically assessed using a tuning fork on bony projections. Pallhypesthesia is not an abnormal sensation triggered by light touch.

C) CORRECT:

Correct -- Dysesthesia is an abnormal and unpleasant sensation (e.g., of burning, pain, or electric shock) that is evoked by a neutral stimulus such as light touch. This patient's current symptoms of burning and electric shock-like pain triggered by contact with her sock, which are reproducible with light touch examination, are consistent with dysesthesia.

D) INCORRECT:

Hyperalgesia is an increased sensitivity to painful stimuli. While this patient has increased sensitivity, the abnormal sensations triggered by normally nonpainful stimuli such as light touch are not consistent with hyperalgesia.

E) INCORRECT:

Paresthesia is a spontaneous abnormal sensation such as tingling and pins-and-needles that occurs without external stimulation. While this patient initially experienced paresthesia, her current symptoms are now triggered by light touch.

questions.text: A 45-year-old woman presents with acute onset unilateral facial weakness. Examination reveals inability to wrinkle the left forehead, inability to close the left eye completely, and left-sided facial droop with smiling. Facial sensation is intact to light touch bilaterally. Tongue protrusion is midline and speech is clear. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

A central facial nerve palsy typically spares forehead muscles due to bilateral cortical innervation of the upper facial muscles from both cerebral hemispheres.

B) INCORRECT:

A trigeminal nerve palsy would primarily affect facial sensation and muscles of mastication. This patient has intact facial sensation and the weakness involves muscles of facial expression rather than jaw muscles.

C) INCORRECT:

A hypoglossal nerve palsy affects tongue movement and would cause tongue deviation when protruded. This patient has midline tongue protrusion.

D) CORRECT:

Correct – The inability to wrinkle the forehead on the affected side along with complete unilateral facial weakness indicates a peripheral facial nerve lesion. In peripheral CN VII palsies, all muscles of facial expression are affected on one side because the lesion occurs distal to the bilateral cortical innervation, resulting in loss of forehead wrinkling, eye closure, and lower facial movement.

E) INCORRECT:

Myasthenia gravis typically causes bilateral, fluctuating weakness that worsens with repetitive use. The acute onset of complete unilateral facial weakness without fluctuation is not characteristic of myasthenic weakness patterns.

questions.text: A 52-year-old woman presents with acute onset of low back pain radiating to both legs, progressive bilateral leg weakness, and urinary incontinence developing over 8 hours. Physical examination shows symmetrical bilateral weakness that is greater distally than proximally in the lower extremities, hyperreflexia, and bilateral perianal numbness. Pain and temperature sensation are diminished in the lower extremities and remain intact in the upper extremities. What is the most likely anatomical location of the lesion?

choices.text: Posterior spinal cord at L3–L4 level
Central spinal cord at L1-L2 level
Anterior spinal cord at L1-L2 level

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Posterior cord syndrome causes bilateral loss of proprioception and sense of vibration, but motor function is preserved. Motor weakness and early bladder dysfunction are not consistent with isolated posterior column involvement.

B) INCORRECT:

Central cord syndrome typically affects the upper extremities more than lower extremities and does not cause the specific pattern of bilateral perianal numbness and early bladder incontinence characteristic of sacral segment involvement.

C) INCORRECT:

Cauda equina syndrome typically manifests with a gradual onset, asymmetrical presentation, and areflexic flaccid paresis. Late-onset urinary retention rather than early incontinence and saddle anesthesia pattern are more characteristic than the symmetrical bilateral findings seen in this patient.

D) CORRECT:

Correct -- Conus medullaris syndrome affects the sacral and coccygeal spinal segments at vertebral levels T12–L2. The sudden onset, symmetrical bilateral presentation, hyperreflexic distal paresis, early bladder incontinence, and characteristic perianal numbness with sensory dissociation are classic features of conus medullaris syndrome.

E) INCORRECT:

Anterior cord syndrome causes bilateral motor paralysis and loss of pain and temperature sensation, but it does not specifically cause the symmetrical bilateral perianal numbness and hyperreflexia pattern seen in this patient. Furthermore, early bladder incontinence is not a characteristic of anterior cord syndrome.

questions.text: A 5-year-old boy who recently emigrated from Nigeria is brought to the emergency department because of a 2-day history of lower leg weakness, swallowing difficulty, and drooling of saliva. He has not yet received any childhood vaccinations. Two days after admission, the patient develops shortness of breath. Pulse oximetry shows an oxygen saturation of 64%. Despite resuscitative efforts, the patient dies of respiratory failure. At autopsy, examination of the spinal cord shows destruction of the anterior horn cells. Neurological examination of this patient would have most likely shown which of the following findings?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

The Babinski sign is a primitive reflex mediated by the extrapyramidal tracts. A positive Babinski sign indicates upper motor neuron lesion. It is not seen in lower motor neuron damage.

B) INCORRECT:

Clasp knife spasticity is characterized by an initial resistance to passive movement due to increased muscle tone, which is followed by a sudden decrease in resistance. This is an upper motor neuron sign, which results from a lesion along the descending motor pathways. It is not seen in lower motor neuron damage.

C) CORRECT:

Hyporeflexia is a sign of lower motor neuron lesion and most likely would have been seen in this patient with destruction of anterior horn cells due to poliomyelitis. Other LMN signs include muscle atrophy, fasciculations, and decreased tone. The involvement of respiratory muscles can lead to respiratory failure, as seen here.

D) INCORRECT:

Sensory loss (e.g., fine touch, proprioception, and vibration) would be expected in destruction of the posterior horn cells of the spinal cord. This patient, however, has destruction of the anterior horn cells of the spinal cord, which provide motor innervation to skeletal muscles in the extremities. Sensory loss is not seen in lower motor neuron damage.

E) INCORRECT:

Myoclonus is characterized by brief, shock-like, involuntary twitches of muscles or muscle groups. Myoclonus is an upper motor neuron sign, which results from lesions along the descending motor pathways. It is not seen in lower motor neuron damage.

F) INCORRECT:

A positive pronator drift test is characterized by pronation and drift of the patient's outstretched arms. A positive test can indicate an upper motor neuron lesion but would not be seen in lower motor neuron damage.
questions.hint: This patient's symptoms (lower leg weakness, swallowing difficulty, and drooling of saliva) and history (no vaccinations) raises suspicion for poliomyelitis, which is confirmed by the autopsy findings of destroyed anterior horn cells of the spinal cord. Lesions of axons between anterior horn cells (lower motor neurons) and the relevant muscle tissue lead to lower motor neuron signs (LMN signs).
